api-ref/source/v2/images-sharing-v2.inc.message:
This could use a rewrite.  I guess if we're confident that no one is using owner_is_tenant=False, there's no need to mention that the owner could be a user_id.

I suggest this:

  .. note::
  
     An image member is an identifier for a consumer with whom the image is
     shared.  In OpenStack clouds, where the value of the ``owner`` property
     of an image is a project ID, the appropriate identifier to use for the
     ``member_id`` is the consumer's project ID (which used to be called the
     "tenant ID").
  
     * Image sharing is project-to-project.  Thus *all the individual users
       in the consuming project have access to the image*.  You cannot share
       an image with only one specific user in the target project.

I think we should leave out the other 2 bullet points.  The problem is that if a user does supply a user_id instead of a project_id, glance will return a 200 because it doesn't validate the member_id to make sure it's an existing project ID.  Instead of warning the user about this, I think we should finally fix https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1308484 and validate that the member_id in the request is a tenant_id.  Rajat added code to do this for a cinder feature he worked on in Victoria [0]; it may be possible to do that with glance, too.  But if we don't prioritize that bug, we should probably warn about it here.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/95d00bd7a6658e2cd3066e5ae77d3a9a63bc0c8f/cinder/api/v3/default_types.py#L40

I disagree with Abhishek about this.  The only legitimate values for owner from Wallaby onward are a project ID or None.  The 'or self.user_id' makes sure that this will never be None, so I suspect there's a problem with the test.    Think of it this way ... we will *always* be treating owner as a project ID because there's nothing else it can be (other than None).  So if we stick a user ID in for owner, we'll have something that's syntactically correct, but it will never work because there is no actual project with that ID.

tempest/lib/services/identity/v3/identit.message: pep8: H102: Apache 2.0 license header not found

Could you please expand every docstring so that it includes the link for the documentation of the relevant api? f.e. this one would be:

"""Register an identity provider.

For a full list of available parameters, please refer to the official
API reference:
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3-ext/#register-an-identity-provider
"""
if I get it right, this could have **kwargs argument as well as per the doc there are 2 optional parameters (id and enabled)

I agree but I think the URL does not include the optional parameters "http://example.com/identity/v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers". Also, I have referred to the API implementation of "List Endpoint Groups (https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3-ext/index.html?expanded=list-identity-providers-detail,list-endpoint-groups-detail#list-endpoint-groups)". The optional argument has not been included in implementation. Please provide your suggestions on how I can proceed. Thank you.

The parameters which are in the URLs are named parameters of the methods - let's take register_identity_provider as an example, it has a identity_provider_id argument because the URL takes identity_provider_id ('OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/%s') and it also has a **kwargs argument because the endpoint might take some additional (some of which are optional) parameters (such as domain_id, description, enabled... ) listed in [1].

Now list_identity_providers method doesn't have any named argument as the URL doesn't take any ID ('OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers') but it should have **kwargs as there are a few optional parameters listed in the doc [2] (namely id and enabled). If this client doesn't contain **kwargs, a user using the client won't be able to pass the additional parameters and thus use the endpoint fully (e.g. filter the results based on the enabled attribute).

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3-ext/index.html?expanded=register-an-identity-provider-detail#register-an-identity-provider
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3-ext/index.html?expanded=list-identity-providers-detail#list-identity-providers

to eliminate the over head of networking i first stacked the host and unstacked with RECLONE=Ture

this synced all the repos and enusred my package were up to date.
i then rebooted the vm after unstacking and checkout this patch.

i then timed the running of this patch stacking with RECLONE=True commented out (default to False)

when it completed i unstacked and stacked again with  DEVSTACK_PARALLEL=True

this vm is one of my main dev vms and depening on repo drifft and how many apckage updates i have to do this typically take about 15 mins our betwee about 815-920 seconds

http://paste.openstack.org/show/802007/

with this patch applied the primed run with  DEVSTACK_PARALLEL=False took 
826 seconds which down form 842 seconds in the warmup run.

when is set DEVSTACK_PARALLEL=True it went form 826 to 575
which is roughly a 30% reduction in execution time.


while i was running i had htop open and for all but the very start it was over a load of 2.0 peaking at 3.78 breifle wiht 1-2 mins of execution over 3.

for the non paralle  runs the load avgerage did not peeak above 2.1
and was generally around 1.2  or less.

so while it is not using all the cores aviable to it by any means this patch does indeed seam to imporve the performace of destack when the repos already exist.
this is the case in the ci where zuul has prepared the repos in advance and is also typically the case for most developer as we tend to reuse the same host but unstack and reskack as needed so git clone tend to be a small amount of the time.

one thing that is partcallary notable is the reduction in "Unaccounted time"    from 370 to 74 seconds
some of this became async_wait and we see a slightly higher usage of osc increase form ~220 to 232
but it save about 250 second over all reducing the run time to just over 10 mins.

as i mentioned before my server that is runign the vm has a 2.7Ghz ivybridge processor so its slow singel treaded performacne vs a moderen porcesssor is proably the main bottelneck to may devstack speed.
i suspect the performace imporvemnt may be less on a laptop  or desktop where you might have 4+GHz processor but i think it should be reflective of devstack performance in the gate.

i have partally optimised my home cloud perfomce by using hugepages and host passthough so i suspect the gate vms will actully be slower but i expect the performace imporment to also be larger there as a result.
the other thing to note is this pacth only make nova and keystone run async.

neutron glance cinder and horizon in my deploy were not optimised in the same way. so it this was expaned it may  contntiue to scale well.

extras.d/80-tempest.sh.message:
im not sure how i feel about splitting async call acoss devstack phases.
i thihnk this coudl unfortunately break some plugins.
perhaps on in the tempest case but

the way around that is to make 

async_wait install_tempest callable multiple times

e.g. if i have a plugin that run in post-config that expects tempest to be installed in the install phase
then that pluging could check if DEVSTACK_PARALLE==True and if so call async_wait install_tempest

the the second invocation of "async_wait install_tempest" here would jsut return imediatly since it was already completed.

That's exactly what happens if you wait for something that was already waited for (or never started in the first place). So, yes, I would expect anything that depends on that finishing would wait for it.

this could be good to run in async mode and useful for cases when large number of plugins are enabled. or better to do in install_tempest_plugins() by iterating over each plugins. not blocking for this patch can be done later.
 https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/aa2821eb89ab9c8048509d15fe41215c163d2f50/lib/tempest#L725

Cool, yeah, I feel like there are many other places where we can kick off some of the tempest stuff in the background. I have done some easy and low-hanging fruit with things I am familiar with, but there is much more to do I think.

inc/async.message: nit: ${pidfile}
Oops, yep, half-finished cleanup :P
if we did not remove this pid file we coudl tell the difference between already finished task and one that never ran later.

We don't want to wait on something that isn't a child (anymore) or wait will throw an error. I don't think we need to know whether something was already finished or never started. If you need to know if something was started, you should be looking at the config flags and only use wait for making sure you go after.

so this else is where we woudl end up if we did
async_wait install_tempest
in two places. so i think we actully do want to have this.

the devstack plug will do async_wait install_tempest once and go into the if branch then
lib/tempset will do async_wait install_tempest a second time
so it would never started or already finished.
It would print that, yeah, but that's what the message says ... "not waiting". I can add "or already finished" for clarity.
that never started or already finished
Ack
then this would be where all pid files where cleaned.

may be we can add func name also here for clear logging. ditto for all logging.

local func="$2"
echo "Async job $name running func $func finished successfully"

sure. Technically you can use async_run (and this) to kick off non-function async tasks, so I didn't want to rely too heavily on the fact that we're running a function (although we could just say that everything needs to be wrapped in a function to be async'd I guess).
We should control this directory externally.
Oh, that's totally not what I thought he meant. And yeah, agree with you, not sure why we would need to do that.

adding a varablie like https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/master/stackrc#L48
which can be used to contol the directory that is used to store these files.

given this is under dest however im not sure its requried.

I would never ever use any pattern in devstack to prove that it's some good practice. The codebase is very "unstandardised" so to speak. ;-)

From my POV it makes more sense to init it once and then rely on that fact.

well i could be wong but that the only thing i could think of.

perhaps he ment pull the creation fo this out in to an async_init function so that its not created on each invocation?
that could also delete it if it already existed to ensure it was created clean once at the start of the devstack run?
Okay, I guess I'm not sure why that really matters. The mkdir -p should be uuber trivial if the directory exists, but glad to do it ahead of time if that's more consistent.

Coming back to this after a bunch of stupid mistakes on my part moving this to create-at-init-time, I really think that just the "mkdir -p" right before we use it is superior.

I see a lot of other such behaviors in devstack:

 grep 'mkdir -p' -r * | wc -l
 46

I know not all of those are core features like this, but I'd much rather just be able to use the async functions instead of have to "init" them first. I have some test scripts I use to test the async stuff without having to do a full stack first, and those have to "init" things first now too.

Anyway, not worth arguing over, and the latest rev here does init early, but just want to re-assert myself that I think it's far better to do it here on demand, and there's no reason not to that I can see.

Yup, I meant the directory should be created once when the stacking starts and removed when it finished cleanly (I mentioned this part of the thought elsewhere, sorry for shady comments; see the other thread now as well).
What does that mean?
I'm an anti-fan of silent failures. I would say we should make the code know whether to wait for something or not rather than wait for everything. Perhaps we could register noops?
Ack, I see how you want to use it. That might be problematic with my strict approach. I don't mind it then as I don't have any good advice on how to handle this without overengineering.

well how would you do that and allow devstack plugins to wait on async jobs.

the way its currently structure is as a plugin i can wait on a task that is created by core devstack
in a pahse before devstack normally would wait. the plug will then continue with its execution yeild back to core devstack and when devstack normally waits it ill get this message.

we need to support 2 things waiting on the single async task in such a way as to garunette that neither runs until its complete.

the plugins would never register the task its waiting on in this case its being done by either another plugin or core devstack so im not usre registing a noop would help here. core devstack cant know if a pluging might wait on one of its async task.

This doesn't wait for everything, this *is* a no-op. And, it's not a silent failure.

This allows us to wait for something in more than one place, and not block or fail on the second. It also lets us wait for things without checking config first. For example, if glance requires cinder to be started first in some situations (which it does), it's so much cleaner to just let glance say "I need to stop here until after cinder has started" without needing to do that only if cinder is configured to run.
I think it should be "has already been waited for" as that is when we delete the ini.
OK, then please amend. 😊
Sure.
This doesn't work as expected because the file gets sourced before stackrc. If you don't set DEVSTACK_PARALLEL to exactly "True" in your rc file it won't be activated.

Fair enough, but since this is an inc/ thing I'm not sure what to do to change it, other than move this elsewhere further from this code, or just check to see if it's set at all.

Anyway, hopefully not a blocker such that I can revise this in a subsequent patch since this has been queued for quite some time :)

manila/share/drivers/cephfs/driver.py.message: In newer ceph versions we call "namespace_isolated" what we used to call "data_isolated". We need to continue getting data_isolated from extra_specs for backwards compatibility. Do we also want to look for namespace_isolated?

ceph_volume_client library creates shares/subvolumes that are RADOS namespace isolated by default. So we always need to set the`--namespace_isolated` flag when creating subvolumes with the ceph-mgr volumes interface.

Data isolated option tells the ceph_volume_client to create a separate data pool for a share. Ceph-mgr volumes can't do that now. Also, creating data pools for each share is not scalable and an option we might want to deprecate. That's an another discussion though. Maybe for now, setting data isolated can be a no op.

We're not getting any namespaced object logs in the job because the server doesn't have the objects:

  error: the server doesn't have a resource type "clusters"
  error: the server doesn't have a resource type "helmrelease"
  error: the server doesn't have a resource type "kubeadmconfigs"
  error: the server doesn't have a resource type "kubeadmconfigtemplates"
  error: the server doesn't have a resource type "kubeadmcontrolplanes"
  error: the server doesn't have a resource type "machinedeployments"

Can we handle that error instead of dropping the other objects collected?

i agree, my comment was more about correctly identifying the list of objects, so that we do not encounter errors which lead to no object data being included, which looks to be the case right now. if we want to just ignore errors when a given object type is not found, then static list should work.

Rather than statically defining the lists, they can be dynamically looked up via:

kubectl api-resources -o name --namespeced=false
kubectl api-resources -o name --namespeced=true

that is a bad idea, it can take a very long time to do that. we have tested and it turned out to be 10-40 minutes, depending on the system, we have well defined list of objects that we need defined here https://review.opendev.org/c/airship/vino/+/774565/4/roles/vino-describe-kubernetes-objects/tasks/main.yaml 
and that is where it should be corrected.

But please lets do it in the next patchset, i thought we have agreed to speed things up. The logs are crucial for development here. and if we are getting some unwanted stdout, we can survive that, and fix in upcoming patchset.

neutron/services/trunk/rpc/server.py.message: That will work because when the port is being migrated, the active binding is the ORIGIN host, that contains the "migrating_to" key in the profile.

With multiple port binding feature, once the migration is done, the port portbinding should point to the destination host. This is when the portbinding is changed. When "migrating_to" key is still in the portbinding dictionary, the port is still being migrated and we can't set the binding to the dest host yet.

What I think is happening is a race condition as in [1]:
- Ports are created in destination host.
- Ports portbinding is updated, now only destination host is defined.
- Ports are set as ACTIVE from the destination host agent.
- Ports are set as DOWN (because are deleted) from the origin host.

Can you test [1] in your environment?

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/766277

We had a meeting to discuss this patch. There are two issues (interrelated):

1) Set the correct subport bindings.
When the trunk is created in the destination host, the subports are updated (following the code described in Slawek's comment). This is the only place that happens and this is why we need to set the correct host (the destination host). That

2) When the trunk port is migrated, set the subports status to ACTIVE.
This is fixed with this code. If the subport binding information is correct (destination host), when the OVS agent updates the port information, the ACTIVE status will be set from the destination host. The DOWN status from the source host will be skipped.

I have this patch in my env but the issue with subports is a bit different.
It is race between Nova-compute and neutron-ovs-agent:
1. nova-compute on destination host creates trunk bridge as part of the L1 wiring,
2. this bridge is then wired by trunk driver: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ab8a17c6a4902bb94c95f3e763eab0481e1e0c43/neutron/services/trunk/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovsdb_handler.py#L152 and as part of that handle_trunk_add method it will call wire_subports_for_trunk(): https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ab8a17c6a4902bb94c95f3e763eab0481e1e0c43/neutron/services/trunk/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovsdb_handler.py#L416
3. This method will call server through rpc and on the server side it will call https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ab8a17c6a4902bb94c95f3e763eab0481e1e0c43/neutron/services/trunk/rpc/server.py#L83 - this method will then get trunk's port, see https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ab8a17c6a4902bb94c95f3e763eab0481e1e0c43/neutron/services/trunk/rpc/server.py#L128 and based on the binding_host of that port it will update subports.

The problem is that trunk's port can still not be updated by nova that migration is finished really. And then we ends up in that issue described in the bug here.
In fact, when I put simple sleep(20) in the L127 here migration worked fine for me and subports were updated properly.

Now the reason why I want to use such "hack" with this migration_to host is simple. It will be easy to backport fix to the stable branches also.
Otherwise we would probably need to update rpc messages format to be able to send back to agent list of "failed" subports and agent would need to try to wire such trunk again in such case. Currently there is no such possibility there.

zuul/ansible/logconfig.py.message:
I may be missing something, but I can not see anywhere that "formatters" supports a "class" field?

https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.config.html#logging-config-dictschema

 The dictionary passed to dictConfig() must contain the following keys:
 ...
 formatters - the corresponding value will be a dict in which each key is a formatter id and each value is a dict describing how to configure the corresponding Formatter instance.

 The configuring dict is searched for keys format and datefmt (with defaults of None) and these are used to construct a Formatter instance.

I'm not really convinced this works ... and I'm not sure what logs to look at to confirm that?  I don't think any of the successful tox runs actually keep the zuul logs to inspect?

It works.  I tested this before submitting it.  If you want, we could create a unit test for it.

This is why class works: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/logging/config.py#L670

It mirrors the stanza below in handlers.  But I agree, it's undocumented.  It's hard to say whether that's an oversign or intentional.  We may be able to use this approach instead which is fully documented but more verbose: https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.config.html#user-defined-objects

That makes it seem more like an oversight in the docs to me.  My guess is the intent is to use 'class' if it subclasses the built-in formatter class (as we do) and '()' if the formatter takes entirely different args.

Thanks; so I wasn't *totally* crazy not having seen this before 😊

We should be able to codify the following into a test:

  $ virsh secret-list

  [..] Ensure a secret is present for the encrypted volume

  $ virsh domblklist $instance

  [..] Ensure the encrypted volume is attached to the instance

  $ qemu-img info --force-share $path

  [..] Ensure the encrypted volume has a disk format of LUKS

$path in the file command can be a normal block device or filesystem path *or* a rbd URI in the format rbd:$volume:id=$user. We should be able to detect what's being used in the output of domblklist and build that URI if required. We might end up needing a configurable for the $user part but I'll check to see if there's another way of digging that out of the domain without needing that.

are there any stuck config out of date alarms on initial bootstrap and after host-unlock with this update? 
(As these may have been masked previously as noted in commit text).

The config out-of-date alarms that occur when docker params are updated get cleared after a lock/unlock and I did not see them on initial bootstrap. I do not know of other services, other than docker, where parameters updates require a reboot and the reboot flag is not set to True.

I know it isn't being used below, but I think you should set the config_uuid here for consistency. I'm surprised that pylint doesn't complain about this. Also, please add code at the top of this function to set config_uuid to None.
Thank you Bart. I see what you mean.

Made the requested changes for consistency, as suggested, and for support of future enhancement for a runtime manifest. I could not find the requirement in either pylint or pep8, to assign the return value to a variable even when there is no immediate use for it. There are about 10 other similar calls in manager.py, in different functions. We may want to refactor them at some point.

Thanks Carmen. I was thinking of pylint error used-before-assignment (E0601). However, this error doesn't catch usages within a conditional, which is the case here. If you open this file in PyCharm, it shows that the usages of both personalities and config_uuid in the "if do_apply" statement are all dangerous because they are not always set.

specs/wallaby/store-volume-format-info.r.message:
This was part of original spec but unsure if we want to do this or not.
Also will require MV bump if we plan to include this.
Done
IMO we shouldn't return this in the volume detail API -- it's relevant for attachments but not top-level volume info.

It might make sense to explain why this is a problem for fs drivers, namely: in order to perform some operations, they may convert a volume into a qcow2 file, though this is transparent to the user.  In the current situation, with no format info stored, these drivers check to see if the volume is still raw or is a qcow2.  But if a user has stored their own qcow2 into a raw volume, this fools the driver into thinking the volume itself is a qcow2, when in fact it's a raw volume that happens to contain a qcow2, and this leads to complications.   Thus we need to actually store format info instead of guessing.
Done

add "because all filesystem volumes always begin in raw format" (assuming that's true).  Is this going to be a problem for existing volumes stored in an fs backend?  How do you propose to handle existing volumes?

That's not true. creating raw or qcow2 volumes depend on the config option which is unique for every fs type driver[1], eg: nfs_qcow2_volumes, nexenta_qcow2_volumes etc
For existing volumes, my plan is to execute qemu-img info and store the format in admin_metadata, will update it.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/remotefs.py#L314-L318

Thanks for the explanation.  I'm confused where you say "The "format" field will have a default "raw" format for all filesystem type drivers.", but I wonder if that's a holdover from when you were thinking of this being a new column in the database.  I think what you want to say is that the format field will be created by FS drivers at the time of volume creation (so it won't have a default value, it will be whatever the driver is configured to use).  But it will definitely be there and be populated, which is the key point.
With default i was referring to "if the config option isn't set, the default format of volumes created is 'raw'" but you're right, this seems very confusing. Will update it.
So basically, the alternative is to try to make better guesses, and we've already seen that this doesn't work.  It's better to explicitly store the format.

This changes the response and will require a new microversion.  Does it make sense to include this as part of the connection_info?  That's defined as an arbitrary JSON object, so it wouldn't require a mv bump.

It's not a problem to have a new microversion if that's the correct thing to do here.  But note that you'll have to have this for all attachments if you change the attachment response.  (You won't have to store it in the DB, but you'll need to include '"format": null' in the response.)
Done
OK, let's see what Eric thinks.
Doing this as part of the connection_info sounds good -- it's only used somewhere the connection_info would be consumed anyway.

Honestly i don't have an issue since we fetch the connection_info in the glance cinder store[1]
and can add an additional attachment get call to get the format but i think Eric had some concerns regarding the same, If he can confirm this isn't an issue then i can update it.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance_store/blob/master/glance_store/_drivers/cinder.py#L640

Thanks for adding this.  You've explained why auto-detection is not a good idea, however, so will this lead to problems?  Do we need a script on the Glance side to set this value for images, because they're the well-known problem case where the volume is "really" raw but there could be a qcow in there.

This might lead to problems but this is the best way in code (that i can think of) to determine if existing volume is raw vs qcow2, maybe there are ways to do it manually by operator but I'm not sure about that
I'm open to suggestions if there are better ways to do it
Glance would require a change to not allow creating/writing image into a qcow2 volume.
I don't think glance would required to set a value for images since we assume glance should only work on "raw" volumes and they can write anything to it.

We may need to think about this some more.  You are right that we don't want glance to worry about setting a value (the way the image is stored in a volume should be transparent to glance), but primary cause of the problem you're fixing is Glance storing qcow2's.  Since the format is being stored in volume admin metadata, it would be possible to write a script to update the format field on all volumes holding images simply using the Images and Block Storage APIs (we don't need direct database access).  So just something to keep in mind.
nit: contain
Done

For instance, if I already have a raw volume that contains a qcow2 header written by the user, the clone operation will add it an admin_metadata ``"format": "qcow2"``, right?
In this case, a subsequent extend operation would consider the raw volume as a qcow2 image, and perform ``qemu-img resize``?

Except for the Glance case, I don't think we have a reliable way to distinguish a user-qcow2 from a backend-qcow2 for legacy volumes.  But if someone thinks of something, we can do it as a follow-up.  A nice thing is that since we're using admin metadata, an operator could add the format to volumes on an ad hoc basis.  I think a good topic for the R-9 midcycle would be to brainstorm how to document this.  I think that Rajat is correct that this feature leaves us no worse off than we currently are with legacy volumes.

It will perform ``qemu-img -f qcow2 resize`` which already happens with format auto-detection.
This feature mostly targets better handling for newly created volumes. That said, for current volumes, we can improvise on the handling, like Brian mentioned adding a "raw" field for all volumes storing images (since glance should always deal with a raw volume). To mention all the scenarios and their handling in the spec seems like overkill to me and would be better to add/test during code review time IMO.
Got it, sounds good!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
+1

I changed my swift.conf to be rw by root only, then ran as vagrant:

  vagrant@saio:~/swift$  swift-object-relinker relink /etc/swift/object-server/1.conf.d/ --device foo --user vagrant
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/bin/swift-object-relinker", line 7, in <module>
    exec(compile(f.read(), __file__, 'exec'))
  File "/vagrant/swift/bin/swift-object-relinker", line 23, in <module>
    sys.exit(main(sys.argv[1:]))
  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/cli/relinker.py", line 422, in main
    objects_per_second=objects_per_second)
  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/cli/relinker.py", line 193, in relink
    policy.load_ring(swift_dir)
  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/common/storage_policy.py", line 377, in load_ring
    self.object_ring = Ring(swift_dir, ring_name=self.ring_name)
  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/common/ring/ring.py", line 275, in __init__
    validate_configuration()
  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/common/utils.py", line 568, in validate_configuration
    validate_hash_conf()
  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/common/utils.py", line 250, in validate_hash_conf
    with open(SWIFT_CONF_FILE) as swift_conf_file:
IOError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/etc/swift/swift.conf'

The stack trace is bit deceptive because it is raised *after* drop_privileges is called, so how is it not also raised when I run using sudo with --user vagrant?

Tim helped me see that validate_hash_conf() is tried *early* when the utils module is loaded, but any exception is squashed if that fails. Hence the later exception when running as vagrant, when validate_hash_conf is called again while loading rings.

When running as root, the early validate_hash_conf() succeeds and the later call, after privileges are dropped to vagrant, is not required, so no exception.

swift/container/sharder.py.message: should we support 0 (or unlimited) max_shrinking and maybe even max_expanding? Could be useful in our deleted root container case 😊

The if's for 219 amd 230 can both match because:
  proposed_object_count <= merge_size
  proposed_object_count >= merge_size

Ie when proposed_object count == merge_size. The way the code works, it's probably ok, and it just means it hits the line, the shardrange is added tothe sequence and then the loop is broken.. just hoping there is an edge case here we're missing. Or if we want to act like other sharder things where we decide <= and > or visa-versa.

the test at line 219 is to decide if the current shard should be shrunk.

the test here at line 230 is to decide if we should bother looking for more shards to append to the sequence, so I think the <= vs >= does make sense. Considering the edge case, at line 219 it's ok to append this shard if the proposed count == merge size, at line 230 we want to break if the proposed count == merge size, because we do not want to add any more to the object count.

So in theory, if we want to use root-container driven shrinking, this is great, however the doner needs the acceptor in it's shard table. But looking at the code, the fact that we are inserting the expanded acceptor into the root container mean it should now overlap with the donor so when the doner shard is audited it should pull it and the accpter down from the root container. And therefore cleave itself?

I think that should work. Let me check what's happening on clays patches probe test in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/771086

yes, the changes recently made here https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/d277960161119face2eb9d617822b2645f19b2c1/swift/container/sharder.py#L785-L813 facilitate this - the donor fetches itself from root (and learns it is shrinking) AND fetches the overlapping acceptor from root, which is sufficient for it to start shrinking (cleaving to acceptor).

I think there is a wrinkle when the acceptor needs to be the root - I am working on that right now.

One thought is that we can make the container-server (or even the proxy if we want to keep the sharding decision in there because we use internal client) a little smarter. And when we get shard ranges from root and there is only 1 shardrange in the shrinking state that we include it's own_own_shardrange in the response. Then we'd have the root in the other_shard_ranges above?

Other is inserting one as we have the root path in metadata in the shard, like I did in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/771343. But maybe inserting shard ranges from a shard goes against the whole root side sharding, were we are expecting decisions to be made at the root side.

My dodgy hack to get this working was to:

diff --git a/swift/container/server.py b/swift/container/server.py
index 0292320..7a5d2e0 100644
--- a/swift/container/server.py
+++ b/swift/container/server.py
@@ -762,6 +762,14 @@ class ContainerController(BaseStorageServer):
             container_list = broker.get_shard_ranges(
                 marker, end_marker, includes, reverse, states=states,
                 include_deleted=include_deleted, fill_gaps=fill_gaps)
+            if len(container_list) == 1 and  \
+                    all([sr.state == ShardRange.SHRINKING 
+                         for sr in broker.get_shard_ranges()]) \
+                    and broker.is_root_container():
+                root_sr = broker.get_own_shard_range()
+                root_sr.update_state(ShardRange.ACTIVE,
+                                     state_timestamp=Timestamp.now())
+                container_list.append(root_sr)
         else:
             resp_headers = gen_resp_headers(info, is_deleted=is_deleted)
             if is_deleted:

So the container server will return the root SR in active state ready for shrinking. So good news this works. But if we go down this path we need to double check our guards and maybe do it in a better place? At the moment it's:

  - If we're only returning one range (no other acceptors because they're all shrinking)
  - All the shard ranges are shrinking.
  - And its a root container (as we don't want shards inserting themselves potentually?).

But it worked on clay's relcaim probe test I ran this patches version of the compact command on  a root container, ran the container replicators, ran the sharders (a few times to make sure it was all cleaved), ran the updaters and replicators and things started disappearing (after reclaim ages).

Although I'm not sure I like going through all the shard ranges again in the all, as I've just hacked it on to the end rather then rework the GET so we can this all shrink info for "free"

I guess as this code stands the length is going to be 1, as you are passing in 1, 1 to find_compactable_shard_sequences.

Still I like this, so logging wont need to change when/if we change the default from 1 😊
I thought this function could return multiple pairs -- shouldn't this be -1?

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/n.message:
It varies depending on deployment situations. For example, in my devstack env on a baremetal with vxlan, the default MTU is 1450, so I cannot create a network without changing the value.

My suggestion is to accept a blank as MTU which lets neutron decide the default MTU value.
From the implementation perspective, if 'mtu' is blank, 'mtu' is not specified in "params" below.
Yeah, I've thought about it, thanks! Also accepting a blank field will reduce test changes too.
Is this needed? MTU 2GB is not realistic. Deployments have specific max values per network technologies and network configurations and the values would be much smaller than this value (2147483647)

NOTE: 4GB is just a theoretical maximum value in IPv6, so there is no practical reason we should set the max value here.

The similar thing can be applied to the min value. The min value is different depending on which IP version (IPv4 vs IPv6). IPv6 requires 1280 bytes. I think we can defer more strict check to neutron API. Let's keep 68 as it is true at least for IPv4.
There's a note about even 4GB here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1859362. But I agree, we do not need this cap it in Horizon. Thank you for your review!
MTU is not for connection. This controls the max packet size the nwtwork created can be forwarded. Could you consider rephrasing it to something more appropriate?
Is "local" necessary? If so what does "local" mean?
This is unnecessary. I think you use the same pattern for az_hints, but az_hints is a conditional field (L.78-90) but mtu is not.
